author: @haywirelive
text: This way works exactly the same and is more memory efficient:  class App(Tk):     def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):          Tk.__init__(self, *args, **kwargs)          self.frame = Variable()         self.mainframe = Frame(self)          self.mainframe.pack(side="top", fill="both", expand = True)         self.mainframe.grid_rowconfigure(0, weight=1)         self.mainframe.grid_columnconfigure(0, weight=1)                  self.show_frame(StartPage)     def show_frame(self, cont, *args, **kwargs):          if type(self.frame) == 'tkinter.Frame':             self.frame.destroy()         self.frame = cont(self.mainframe, self, *args, *kwargs)         self.frame.grid(row=0, column=0, sticky="nsew")

author: @bryanoakley5189
text: This video has several errors just in the first couple of minutes. For example, you'll _never_ see "def __init__(self, *, **)`. Why? It is invalid syntax. As for the bit about never having to pass self, while technically true in a sense, "self" is an integral part of what makes objects work. It must always be there if you are creating methods that belong to the object.

author: @randomstranger1960
text: Your descriptions of both grid and pack are very flawed. Pack doesn't just "stuff things in there". It's very deterministic, and extremely good at specific types of layouts. Also, for grid_rowconfigure the first parameter isn't the minimum size. It represents the row or column number -- in this case, you're configuring row zero and column zero. The weight isn't a priority per se. It tells tkinter how to allocate extra space -- rows and columns with more weight get proportionally more extra space than rows and columns with less weight.

author: @randomstranger1960
text: You say "self doesn't have to be there" which is simply not true. If you're defining a method of a class, you _must_ have the "self" parameter. You are correct that you can name it whatever you want (though it's a bad idea to name it anything other than "self" if you want other python programmers to be able to understand your code), but there _must_ be a parameter there. And it's not because "Guido says", but because that's how python is defined to work.

author: @randomstranger1960
text: Your `show_frame` method takes a parameter which you named "cont" (which you say is short for "controller"). This parameter does _not_ represent the controller. In the original stackoverflow answer from which you copied this code, the parameter was "c" which stood for "class" since it represented the name of the clas that you're switching to. Renaming it to "cont" as short for "controller" makes your code harder to understand.

author: @samqueen3757
text: #If anyone needs the code  from tkinter import * import tkinter as tk   LARGE_FONT= ("Verdana", 12)    class SeaofBTCapp(tk.Tk):      def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):          tk.Tk.__init__(self, *args, **kwargs)         container = tk.Frame(self)          container.pack(side="top", fill="both", expand=True)          container.grid_rowconfigure(0, weight=1)         container.grid_columnconfigure(0, weight=1)          self.frames = {}          frame = StartPage(container, self)          self.frames[StartPage] = frame          frame.grid(row=0, column = 0, sticky="nsew")          self.show_frame(StartPage)      def show_frame(self, cont):          frame = self.frames[cont]         frame.tkraise()   class StartPage(tk.Frame):      def __init__(self, parent, controller):         tk.Frame.__init__(self, parent)         label = tk.Label(self, text="Start Page", font=LARGE_FONT)         label.pack(pady=10, padx=10)   app = SeaofBTCapp() app.mainloop()

author: @GeekZonelive
text: #Code cheat sheet -  Like this comment so that everyone can see import tkinter as tk LARGE_FONT=("Verdana", 12) class SeaofBTCapp (tk.Tk):     def __init__(self,*args,**kwargs):         tk.Tk.__init__(self, *args, **kwargs)         container = tk.Frame(self)         container.pack(side="top", fill="both", expand = True)          container.grid_rowconfigure(0, weight=1)         container.grid_columnconfigure(0, weight=1)          self.frames = {}         frame = StartPage(container, self)         self.frames[StartPage] = frame         frame.grid(row=0, column = 0, sticky="nsew")         self.show_frame(StartPage)       def show_frame(self,cont):         frame = self.frames[cont]         frame.tkraise()   class StartPage(tk.Frame):     def __init__(self, parent, controller):         tk.Frame.__init__(self,parent)         label = tk.Label(self, text="Start Page", font=LARGE_FONT)         label.pack(pady=10, padx=10)    app= SeaofBTCapp() app.mainloop()

author: @zupazupa11
text: there's a bit easier method to initialize the class:  from tkinter import *  class App(Frame):   def __init__(self, master):       self.grid()       super(App, self).__init__(master)  then the window: root = Tk() application = App(root) root.mainloop() But if u prefer that method, no problem

author: @ECOMMUSK
text: entire code so you know its the same :   __author__ = 'kennytruong' import tkinter as tk   #making an application that can load differnet windows   LARGE_FONT = ("Verdana", 12)   class SeaofBTCapp(tk.Tk): #class called SeaofBTCapp, wants to inherit the TK class within tkinter      def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): #this method is like initialize, and so IF WE CALL THIS CLASS, THIS AUTOMATICALLY RUNS     #self is implied, *args means its open ended and we can pass as much as you want through     #**kwargs is keyword arguments, these are needed         tk.Tk.__init__(self, *args, **kwargs)         container = tk.Frame(self)     #make our frame         container.pack(side="top", fill="both", expand = True)         #fill - fill the space allotted, expand - will it expand beyond the limits we set?         container.grid_rowconfigure(0, weight=1) #0 is minimum size         container.grid_columnconfigure(0, weight=1)          self.frames = {} #create dictionary         frame = StartPage(container, self) #Startpage is initial page we run on     #were gonna make a bunch of frames and slap em inside a container and we alternate frames for multiple windows         self.frames[StartPage] = frame         frame.grid(row=0, column=0, sticky="nsew") #assigning some frame to a grid         #sticky is alignment, so sticky="n" means aligning everything on the north, etc         self.show_frame(StartPage)      def show_frame(self, cont): #pass self and controller         frame = self.frames[cont]         frame.tkraise() #run this method tkraise on frame.  class StartPage(tk.Frame): #inherits the things from tk.Frame      def __int__(self, parent, controller): #runs by itself         tk.Frame.__init__(self, parent) #parent is the SeaofBTCapp class         label = tk.Label(self, text="Start Page", font=LARGE_FONT) #class creates an object, returns that object to variable "label"         #the line above basically runs those parameters         label.pack(pady=10, padx=10)  app = SeaofBTCapp() app.mainloop() #inherited from SeaofBTCapp
